title: Team
text:
Our dedicated team at the Mental Health Epidemiology Group is composed of skilled researchers, educators, and professionals committed to advancing the field of mental health research. Together, we strive to make a positive impact on mental health outcomes and contribute to the well-being of individuals and communities.
Prof. Dr. Maurício Scopel Hoffmann





Position: Professor (tenure) & Lab Head
Dr. Hoffmann is an Adjunct Professor of psychiatry at the Federal University of Santa Maria (UFSM) and the Graduation Program in Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences (PPGPsiq) at Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul (UFRGS). Dr. Hoffmann uses psychometric and structural equation modeling techniques as an approach to his research questions around psychiatric nosology and epidemiology.
Prof. MSc. João Pedro Gonçalves Pacheco





Position: Assistant Professor
Dr. Pacheco is an assistant professor (tenure track) of psychiatry at UFSM and PhD student at the PPGPsiq at UFRGS in psychiatric epidemiology.
MD. João Villanova do Amaral





Position: Research Associate
Dr. do Amaral holds an MD degree (UFSM) and is currently a Master’s candidate at the PPGPsiq UFRGS.
Mr. Ighor Porto





Position: Research Assistant
Mr. Porto is a dedicated medical student with a passion for mental health epidemiology.
Ms. Gabriele dos Santos Jobim

title: Courses
text:
Data Analysis in Mental Health: Observational Studies and Psychometrics in R Language
Portuguese title: Análise de Dados em Saúde Mental: Estudos Observacionais e Psicometria em Linguagem R
Course Description:
This course is designed to equip participants with essential skills in analyzing mental health data using R, a powerful and versatile programming language for statistical computing and graphics.
Course Location:
Federal University of Santa Maria, Brazil.


Advanced Biostatistics: Psychometrics and Structural Equation Modelling Applied to Psychopathology
Portuguese title: Bioestatística Avançada: Psicometria e Modelagem de Equações Estruturais Aplicadas à Psicopatologia
Course Description:
This course is designed for master’s and doctoral students who seek to gain a comprehensive understanding and practical application of structural equations and their various forms in the field of psychopathology. The course focuses on exploring and utilizing techniques such as factor analysis, cross-lagged analysis, and latent growth modeling. The technical training provided in this course equips participants with the skills to conduct structural equations using the statistical programming language R.
Course Location:
Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil.

title: Mental Health Epidemiology Group
text:
The Mental Health Epidemiology Group is a dedicated research team based at the Federal University of Santa Maria. Our passion lies in the field of psychiatric epidemiology, nosology, and psychometrics. At our core, we aim to deepen our understanding of mental health patterns, influences, and outcomes through comprehensive research and disseminate this knowledge to students, professionals, and the wider community through educational courses. By bridging the gap between research and practice, we strive to make a positive impact on mental health policies and interventions in Brazil and beyond.


We delve into a wide range of research areas that have significant implications for mental health and well-being. Our primary research focuses include:


Exploring the prevalence, incidence, risk factors, and distribution of mental disorders in populations to inform public health strategies.



Investigating the classification and categorization of mental disorders.



Developing and validating reliable measurement tools to assess mental health constructs and aid in accurate data collection.






Our team of researchers conducts studies that contribute to the scientific understanding of mental health phenomena. By employing rigorous methodologies and innovative approaches, we seek to advance knowledge in the field.



As part of our commitment to knowledge dissemination, we offer specialized courses on mental health epidemiology, nosology, and psychometrics. These courses cater to students, academics, mental health professionals, and anyone interested in gaining expertise in these areas.



In addition to our research and courses, we are dedicated to developing tools that assist researchers and clinicians in their endeavors related to various aspects of mental health.




We welcome individuals who share our passion for mental health research and advocacy to join us in our endeavors. Whether you are a student, researcher, or practitioner, there are opportunities for collaboration, participation in our courses, and contributing to meaningful research.



If you have any inquiries, want to collaborate, or seek more information about our research group and courses, please feel free to get in touch with us:
Email: joaopgp123@gmail.com
Thank you for visiting our website.

title: Resources
text:
Harmony
If you are a researcher in need of harmonizing and comparing questionnaires, check out Harmony! This valuable tool can save you time and enhance the quality of your research. It is being developed by a collaborative team from the UK and Brazil (Dr. Hoffmann), and is funded by the Wellcome Trust (Data Prize).
See how it works:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cEZppTBj1NI&ab_channel=Harmony


DSM-XC Calculator
The DSM Level 1 Cross-Cutting Symptom Measure (DSM-XC) (https://www.psychiatry.org/getmedia/e0b4b299-95b3-407b-b8c2-caa871ca218d/APA-DSM5TR-Level1MeasureAdult.pdf) calculator allows for visualizing the change from the pre- to the post-test probability of 8 mental disorders. The user can select from the multiple psychopathological domains the DSM-XC measures, the adverbial framing that was used and if the test was positive or negative. The acompanying paper is currently under review. Estimates are based on the latest assessment of 22 years old of the 1993 Pelotas Birth Cohort.
https://pacheco-jpg.shinyapps.io/dsm_xc_shiny_app/


PHQ-9 Calculator
The Patient Health Questionnaire-9 calculator, developed by our team, computes your standardized depression score, compared with the Brazilian population.The standardized score (T Score) is a measure that uses a method called Item Response Theory, based on the analyses of answers to the same questions by Brazilians in the National Health Survey of 2019 (Damiano et al. 2023 - https://doi.org/10.47626/1516-4446-2022-2945). This standardized score ranges from 0 to 100, with 0 to 50 representing no symptoms, 50 to 60 representing a few symptoms, between 60 and 70 as moderate symptoms, and above 70 as severe symptoms that warrant clinical attention for depression.
https://mheg.shinyapps.io/phq9-score/
